title: 113_s2354
content: The Act titled "DHS Cybersecurity Workforce Recruitment and Retention Act of 2014" aims to enhance cybersecurity recruitment and retention efforts within the Homeland Security Act of 2002. It introduces Section 226 specifically addressing cybersecurity recruitment and retention. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as "appropriate committees of Congress," "collective bargaining agreement," "excepted service," and "preference eligible." The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like "qualified position" and "Senior Executive Service" in relation to cybersecurity responsibilities within the Department. The Secretary has the authority to establish positions, appoint personnel, and determine pay rates in the excepted service. The Secretary has the authority to establish positions and appoint personnel necessary for cybersecurity responsibilities within the Department, including senior level and Senior Executive Service positions. The Secretary has the authority to establish positions and appoint personnel for cybersecurity responsibilities within the Department, including senior level and Senior Executive Service positions. The Secretary can fix compensation for individuals in qualified positions without regard to other laws. The Secretary shall determine rates of basic pay for qualified positions in relation to pay rates for comparable employees. The Secretary may establish positions and appoint personnel for cybersecurity responsibilities within the Department, including senior level and Senior Executive Service positions. Rates of pay for employees in comparable positions in the Department of Defense may be determined without regard to other laws. The Secretary may provide additional compensation, incentives, and allowances based on title 5 authorities. The Secretary may provide employees in qualified positions with compensation, benefits, incentives, and allowances not exceeding those authorized for comparable positions under title 5, United States Code. Employees in qualified positions are eligible for allowances under section 5941 of title 5, United States Code, on the same basis as other employees covered by that section. The Secretary shall submit a report to Congress with a plan for the use of authorities provided under this subsection, ensuring collective bargaining agreements remain effective. Required regulations will be coordinated by the Secretary. The Secretary, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, will prescribe regulations for the administration of this section. An annual report detailing the application process, candidate assessment, veterans' preference adherence, and recruitment plans for qualified positions will be submitted to Congress. The annual report will detail measures used to measure progress, actions taken to fulfill critical needs, integration of planning and actions into workforce planning, and metrics on hiring and placement of employees in qualified positions, including veterans. The annual report will include data on separations, retirements, and incentives for employees in qualified positions, as well as training for supervisors. Employees hired under the new authority will have a 3-year probationary period. Incumbents of existing competitive service positions are also addressed. The annual report will include data on separations, retirements, and incentives for employees in qualified positions, as well as training for supervisors. Employees hired under the new authority will have a 3-year probationary period. Incumbents of existing competitive service positions have the right to refuse conversion to the excepted service. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include qualified positions in the excepted service established by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include cybersecurity recruitment and retention measures. The Homeland Security Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act establishes definitions for key terms related to cybersecurity workforce categories and data elements. The Homeland Security Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act defines key terms related to cybersecurity positions within the Department of Homeland Security, including the roles of Department, Director, and Secretary. The Act also mandates the identification and categorization of cybersecurity positions based on the National Cybersecurity Workforce Measurement Initiative. The Homeland Security Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act mandates the identification and categorization of cybersecurity positions based on the National Cybersecurity Workforce Framework report. The Secretary is required to establish procedures to identify open positions with cybersecurity functions and assign appropriate employment codes within specified timeframes. The Secretary assigns employment codes to employees and open positions with cybersecurity functions. A progress report is due within a year of the Act's enactment. Identification of critical cybersecurity specialty areas is required annually starting from the assignment of employment codes. The Secretary, in consultation with the Director, must annually identify Cybersecurity Work Categories and Specialty Areas of critical need in the Department's cybersecurity workforce. A report describing these areas and substantiating the critical need designations must be submitted to the Director. The Director will provide timely guidance for this identification process. The Secretary, in consultation with the Director, must identify Cybersecurity Work Categories and Specialty Areas with acute and emerging skill shortages. A progress report on the implementation of this identification process must be submitted to congressional committees. The Comptroller General of the United States will analyze and monitor the implementation of the identified areas. The Secretary, in consultation with the Director, must identify Cybersecurity Work Categories and Specialty Areas with skill shortages. The Comptroller General will analyze and monitor the implementation of these areas and submit a report to congressional committees within 3 years of the Act's enactment.
